[[Commander of the Royal Victorian Order]] |laterwork= }} [[Admiral of the Fleet (Royal Navy)|Admiral of the Fleet]] '''Sir Frederick Charles Doveton Sturdee, 1st Baronet''' {{postnominals|country=GBR|size=100%|sep=,|GCB|KCMG|CVO}} (9 June 1859 – 7 May 1925) was a [[Royal Navy]] officer. After training as a torpedo officer, he commanded two different cruisers and then three different battleships before becoming commander of the [[1st Battle Squadron (United Kingdom)|1st Battle Squadron]] of the [[Home Fleet]]. He went on to command the 3rd Cruiser Squadron and then the 2nd Cruiser Squadron. Just before the start of the [[First World War]] Sturdee became Chief of War Staff at the [[Admiralty]]. In November 1914 the Royal Navy suffered a serious defeat at the [[Battle of Coronel]]. In response Sturdee was sent to the [[South Atlantic Station|South Atlantic]] to seek out the German squadron, commanded by Graf [[Maximilian von Spee]], which had caused the damage at Coronel. On 8 December 1914, while coaling at [[Stanley, Falkland Islands|Stanley]], Sturdee encountered von Spee and the subsequent action became known as the [[Battle of the Falkland Islands]]. Von Spee, finding that he was engaged with a superior force, was forced to flee. In the course of the pursuit Sturdee's forces sank almost the entire German squadron. Only one light cruiser escaped but she was hunted down in March 1915. In the closing years of the war Sturdee served as commander of the [[4th Battle Squadron (United Kingdom)|4th Battle Squadron]] in the [[Grand Fleet]] and then as [[Commander-in-Chief, The Nore]]. ==Naval career== ===Early career=== Born the son of Captain Frederick Sturdee RN and Anna Frances Sturdee (née Hodson), Sturdee was educated at the [[Royal Naval School]] at [[New Cross]] and then joined the Royal Navy as a [[cadet]] in the training ship [[HMS Prince of Wales (1860)|HMS ''Britannia'']] on 15 July 1871.{{cite web|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/36364?docPos=1|title=Doveton Sturdee|publisher=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography|accessdate=7 December 2014}} Promoted to [[midshipman]] on 19 July 1873, he was appointed to the [[frigate]] {{HMS|Undaunted|1861|6}}, flagship of the [[China Station]] in 1876.Heathcote, p. 238 Promoted to [[sub-lieutenant]] on 9 June 1878 and to [[lieutenant]] on 7 February 1880,{{London Gazette |issue=24810|date=10 February 1880|supp=|startpage=622|accessdate=7 December 2014}} he joined the [[brig]] {{HMS|Martin|1850|6}} at [[Portsmouth]] in May 1880 and then transferred to the torpedo depot ship {{HMS|Hecla|1878|6}} in the [[Mediterranean Fleet]] in February 1881. He took part in the [[bombardment of Alexandria]] in July 1882 during the [[Anglo-Egyptian War]]. After completing a course on [[torpedo]]es at {{HMS|Vernon|shore establishment|6}} Sturdee became a torpedo officer on {{HMS|Bellerophon|1865|6}}, flagship of the [[North America and West Indies Station]], in 1886 before returning to HMS ''Vernon'' as an instructor in 1889. Promoted to [[commander]] on 30 June 1893,{{London Gazette |issue=26422|date=14 July 1893|supp=|startpage=3981|accessdate=7 December 2014}} he transferred to the [[Admiralty]] as a torpedo specialist in the Directorate of Naval Ordnance. He became commanding officer of the [[cruiser]] {{HMS|Porpoise|1886|6}} on the [[Australian Station]] in November 1897 and became involved in managing the tensions with Germany and the United States over the [[Samoa|Samoan Islands]] in 1899. His handling of this situation, which involved a tense stand-off with the German representatives, earned him his promotion to [[Captain (Royal Navy)|captain]] on 30 June 1899{{London Gazette |issue=27099|date=14 July 1899|supp=|startpage=4345|accessdate=7 December 2014}} and his appointment as a [[Order of St Michael and St George|Companion of the Order of St Michael and St George]] on 1 January 1900.{{London Gazette |issue=27154 |date=16 January 1900|supp=|startpage=286|accessdate=7 December 2014}} Sturdee returned to the Admiralty as assistant director of naval intelligence in 1902, and having been appointed a member, 4th class, of the [[Royal Victorian Order]] on 21 April 1903,{{London Gazette |issue=27560|date=2 June 1903|supp=|startpage=3525|accessdate=7 December 2014}} he became commanding officer of the [[armored cruiser|armoured cruiser]] {{HMS|Bedford|1901|6}} in the [[Home Fleet]] in November 1903. He went on to be commanding officer of the [[battleship]] {{HMS|Bulwark|1899|6}} and Chief of Staff to the Commander-in-Chief of the Mediterranean Fleet in May 1905.Heathcote, p. 239 Advanced to [[Royal Victorian Order|Commander of the Royal Victorian Order]] on 16 April 1906,{{London Gazette |issue=27908 |date=27 April 1906|supp=|startpage=2875|accessdate=7 December 2014}} he became commanding officer of the [[battleship]] {{HMS|King Edward VII}} and then of the battleship {{HMS|New Zealand|1904|6}} in a new role as Chief of Staff of the [[Channel Fleet]] in 1907. He was appointed an [[aide-de-camp]] to [[Edward VII|the King]] on 26 October 1907.{{London Gazette |issue=28079|date=12 November 1907|supp=|startpage=7581|accessdate=7 December 2014}} Promoted to [[rear-admiral]] on 12 September 1908,{{London Gazette |issue=28178|date=18 September 1908|supp=|startpage=6760|accessdate=7 December 2014}} he became Rear Admiral commanding the [[1st Battle Squadron (United Kingdom)|1st Battle Squadron]] of the [[Home Fleet]], with his flag in the battleship {{HMS|St. Vincent|1908|6}}, in 1910. He became President of the Submarine Committee of the Admiralty in early 1911 and then became commander of the 3rd Cruiser Squadron of the Home Fleet, with his flag in the [[cruiser]] {{HMS|Shannon|1906|6}}, in December 1911. He went on to become commander of the 2nd Cruiser Squadron of the Home Fleet, with his flag in the cruiser HMS ''Shannon'' again, in 1913. He was appointed a [[Order of the Bath|Knight Commander of the Order of the Bath]] on 3 June 1913.{{London Gazette |issue=28724 |date=30 May 1913|supp=yes|startpage=3903|accessdate=7 December 2014}} Promoted to [[vice-admiral]] on 13 December 1913,{{London Gazette |issue=28783|date=19 December 1913|supp=|startpage=9338|accessdate=7 December 2014}} he became Chief of War Staff at the Admiralty in July 1914. ===First World War=== [[File:Cfbattlepainting (Retouched).jpg|thumb|left|''Battle of the Falkland Islands'' by [[William Lionel Wyllie]]. ''Scharnhorst'' rolls over and sinks while ''Gneisenau'' continues to fight]] In November 1914 the Royal Navy suffered a serious defeat when it lost two armoured cruisers at the [[Battle of Coronel]]. After [[Winston Churchill]] insisted that Sturdee should not be made a scapegoat for the events at Coronel, Admiral [[John Fisher, 1st Baron Fisher|Lord Fisher]] sent a squadron commanded by Sturdee, with his flag in the [[battlecruiser]] {{HMS|Invincible|1907|6}}, to the [[South Atlantic Station|South Atlantic]] to seek out the German squadron, commanded by Graf [[Maximilian von Spee]], which had caused the damage at Coronel.Massie, p. 248 On 8 December 1914, while coaling at [[Stanley, Falkland Islands|Stanley]], Sturdee encountered von Spee and the subsequent action became known as the [[Battle of the Falkland Islands]]. Von Spee, finding that he was engaged with a superior force, was forced to flee. In the course of the pursuit Sturdee's forces sank almost the entire German squadron, including the [[Scharnhorst-class cruiser|armoured cruiser]]s, {{SMS|Scharnhorst||6}} and {{SMS|Gneisenau||6}}. Only the light cruiser {{SMS|Dresden|1907|6}} escaped but she was hunted down in March 1915.Heathcote, p. 240 For his part in this important naval action Sturdee was created a [[baronet]] on 15 March 1916.{{LondonGazette |issue=29512|date=17 March 1916|supp=|startpage=2932|accessdate=7 December 2014}} [[Image:Frederick Doveton Sturdee 1916 HMS Hercules.jpg|right|thumb|upright|Sturdee on board {{HMS|Hercules|1910|6}} commanding [[4th Battle Squadron (United Kingdom)|4th Battle Squadron]] at the [[Battle of Jutland]].]] Sturdee became commander of the [[4th Battle Squadron (United Kingdom)|4th Battle Squadron]] in the [[Grand Fleet]], with his flag in the battleship {{HMS|Benbow|1913|6}}, in January 1915 and directed his squadron at the [[Battle of Jutland]] in May 1916. He was advanced to [[Order of St Michael and St George|Knight Commander of the Order of St Michael and St George]] on 31 May 1916{{LondonGazette |issue=29751|date=15 September 1916|supp=yes|startpage=9071|accessdate=7 December 2014}} and awarded the Cross of Commander of the French [[Legion of Honour]] on 15 September 1916.{{LondonGazette|issue=29751|supp=yes|startpage=9081|date=15 September 1916|accessdate=7 December 2014}} Promoted to full [[admiral]] on 17 May 1917,{{LondonGazette |issue=30084|date=22 May 1917|supp=|startpage=4942|accessdate=7 December 2014}} Sturdee was appointed Grand Officer of the Italian [[Order of Saints Maurice and Lazarus]] on 11 August 1917,{{LondonGazette|issue=30227|supp=yes|startpage=8208|date=10 August 1917|accessdate=13 December 2014}} and became [[Commander-in-Chief, The Nore]] in March 1918. He was promoted to [[Admiral of the Fleet (Royal Navy)|Admiral of the Fleet]] on his retirement on 5 July 1921{{LondonGazette |issue=32394|date=19 July 1921|supp=|startpage=5733|accessdate=7 December 2014}} and advanced to [[Knight Grand Cross of the Order of the Bath]] on 1 January 1921.{{LondonGazette |issue=32178 |date=1 January 1921 |supp=yes|startpage=4|accessdate=7 December 2014}} ==Personal life== [[Image:DovetonSturdeeGravestoneFrimley.jpg|thumb|upright|Sir Doveton Sturdee's gravestone in the churchyard of St Peter's Church, [[Frimley]].]] In 1882 Sturdee married Marion Andrews (died 1940): they had a son and a daughter. Sturdee retired to [[Camberley]], in [[Surrey]], and died there on 7 May 1925. He was buried in the churchyard of St. Peter's Church in nearby [[Frimley]]. His gravestone incorporates a cross made from the timbers of [[Horatio Nelson, 1st Viscount Nelson|Nelson]]'s ship, {{HMS|Victory}}. His grandson [[William Staveley (Royal Navy officer)|William Staveley]]Heathcote, p. 235 and grandson-in-law [[Edward Ashmore]] were also Admirals of the Fleet.{{LondonGazette|issue=47160|supp=yes|startpage=2825|date=1 March 1977|accessdate=7 December 2014}} ==References== {{Research help|Mil}} {{reflist|30em}} ==Sources== * {{cite book|last=Heathcote |first=Tony |title=The British Admirals of the Fleet 1734 – 1995 |publisher=Pen & Sword Ltd |year=2002 |isbn=0-85052-835-6}} *{{cite book |title=[[Castles of Steel: Britain, Germany, and the Winning of the Great War at Sea]] |last=Massie |first=Robert K. |authorlink=Robert K. Massie |year=2004 |location=London |publisher=[[Jonathan Cape]] |isbn=0-224-04092-8}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Doveton Sturdee}} *{{DP-xlink|http://dreadnoughtproject.org/tfs/index.php/Frederick_Charles_Doveton_Sturdee,_First_Baronet}} *[http://janus.lib.cam.ac.uk/db/node.xsp?id=EAD%2FGBR%2F0014%2FSDEE Biographical information from the Churchill Centre], [[University of Cambridge]]. {{s-start}} {{s-mil}} {{succession box | title=[[Commander-in-Chief, The Nore]] | years=1918–1921 | before=[[George Callaghan|Sir George Callaghan]] | after={{nowrap|[[Hugh Evan-Thomas|Sir Hugh Evan-Thomas]]}}}} {{end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sturdee, Doveton}} [[Category:1859 births]] [[Category:1925 deaths]] [[Category:Royal Navy admirals of World War I]] [[Category:Royal Navy personnel of the Anglo-Egyptian War]] [[Category:Baronets in the Baronetage of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Royal Navy admirals of the fleet]] [[Category:Légion d'honneur recipients]] [[Category:Knights Grand Cross of the Order of the Bath]] [[Category:Knights Commander of the Order of St Michael and St George]] [[Category:Commanders of the Royal Victorian Order]] [[Category:History of the Falkland Islands]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Wen-Hu]]
